results.name: A007918(A138750(n)) = least prime > n/2 if n=2 (mod 3), > 2n otherwise.
comment: This can be considered as an analog of the Collatz (or 3n+1) map on the set of primes, see A138751 and A138754 for details.

Numbers 0,1,2 go immediately to the unique fixed point 2, all others end up in the cycle 7 -> 17 -> 11 -> 7, after a number of iterations given by A138753(A138757(n))-1 (= A138753(n)-2 if n is prime).
link: Index entries for sequences related to 3x+1 (or Collatz) problem
example: a(11) = 7 since 11 = 2 (mod 3), thus A138750(11) = ceil(11/2) = 6, nextprime(6) = 7.
mathematica: np1[n_]:=Module[{x=Ceiling[n/2]},If[PrimeQ[x],x,NextPrime[x]]]; np2[n_]:= Module[{x=2n},If[PrimeQ[x],x,NextPrime[x]]]; Table[If[Mod[n,3]==2, np1[n], np2[n]],{n,0,70}] (* _Harvey P. Dale_, Jul 10 2013 *)
